title: Anti-Markovnikov Hydration

steps.mechanism_hint: Hydroboration-Oxidation adds OH to the less hindered carbon.

explanation: Hydroboration-Oxidation is an Anti-Markovnikov addition of water. It converts Propene to Propan-1-ol by adding OH to the less substituted carbon.

title: Alkyne Synthesis (Step Up)

steps.mechanism_hint: Convert Alcohol to Alkyl Halide first.

explanation: First, convert Ethanol to Chloroethane using SOCl2. Then, treat with Sodium Acetylide (HC≡C-Na+) to perform nucleophilic substitution, extending the chain to But-1-yne.

title: Position Isomerization

steps.mechanism_hint: Markovnikov addition moves Br to the internal carbon.

explanation: Eliminate HBr from 1-Bromopropane using alcoholic KOH to form Propene. Then, add HBr (without peroxide) to follow Markovnikov's rule, placing Br at the more substituted position.

title: Side Chain Oxidation

steps.mechanism_hint: Free radical substitution attacks the benzylic carbon.

explanation: Free radical chlorination (Cl2/hv) targets the benzylic position of Toluene. Subsequent hydrolysis with aqueous KOH replaces the Cl with OH, yielding Benzyl Alcohol.

title: Directing Groups

steps.mechanism_hint: Brominate first because -Br is ortho/para directing.
Nitration occurs at the Para position (Major).

explanation: Bromination comes first because -Br directs Ortho/Para. If we nitrated first, -NO2 would direct Meta. Nitration of Bromobenzene yields the Para isomer as the major product.

title: Ascent of Series (Carbon Step Up)

steps.mechanism_hint: Complete hydrolysis of Nitrile gives Carboxylic Acid.

explanation: Convert Alcohol to Chloride (PCl5). Use KCN to add a carbon (Nitrile). Complete acid hydrolysis of the Nitrile converts -CN to -COOH.

title: Nitrile Synthesis
explanation: Convert Ethanol to Ethyl Chloride (SOCl2). Then use KCN (alcoholic) for nucleophilic substitution to form Propanenitrile, extending the carbon chain.

title: Sandmeyer Reaction
explanation: Aniline is diazotized with NaNO2/HCl at 0-5°C to form Benzene Diazonium Chloride. CuCl/HCl (Sandmeyer) then replaces the diazonium group with Chlorine.

title: Wurtz Reaction

steps.mechanism_hint: Wurtz Reaction doubles the carbon skeleton via the halide.

explanation: Treating 2-Chlorobutane with Sodium in dry ether couples two alkyl groups together (Wurtz Reaction), doubling the structure to form 3,4-Dimethylhexane.

title: Markovnikov Addition

steps.mechanism_hint: Markovnikov addition: H goes to the carbon with more hydrogens.

explanation: Addition of HCl to the alkene follows Markovnikov's rule. The H+ adds to the carbon with more hydrogens, placing the Cl- on the tertiary carbocation.

title: Ascent to Acid
description: Convert Ethyl Chloride to Propanoic Acid
explanation: React Ethyl Chloride with KCN to form Propanenitrile (adding a carbon). Acidic hydrolysis (H3O+) converts the nitrile group (-CN) directly to a carboxylic acid (-COOH).

title: Finkelstein Reaction
explanation: Add HBr with Peroxide (Anti-Markovnikov) to get 1-Bromobutane. Then use NaI in Acetone (Finkelstein Reaction) to exchange Bromine for Iodine via SN2 mechanism.

title: Moving Down the Chain
explanation: Dehydrohalogenation (Alc KOH) forms Propene. Hydroboration-Oxidation then adds water Anti-Markovnikov to give 1-Propanol, effective moving the functional group to the end.

title: Haloform Test

steps.mechanism_hint: Oxidation followed by cleavage. Only for Methyl Ketones/Alcohols.

explanation: Iodine and NaOH oxidize the methyl ketone/alcohol to a carboxylate and produce yellow Iodoform (CHI3) precipitate. This is a specific test for methyl carbinols/ketones.

title: Nucleophilic Substitution

steps.mechanism_hint: Nitration first. NO2 withdraws e-, making C-Cl susceptible.
Nucleophilic substitution works now due to -NO2 group.

explanation: Nitrate Chlorobenzene to introduce -NO2 at Para position. The electron-withdrawing nitro group activates the ring for Nucleophilic Aromatic Substitution (Dow Process) to replace Cl with OH.

title: Isomerization of Halide
explanation: Eliminate HBr to form Propene. Then apply Kharasch Effect (HBr + Peroxide) for Anti-Markovnikov addition, moving Bromine to the primary carbon.

title: Chain Doubling

steps.mechanism_hint: Wurtz Reaction connects two ethyl groups.

explanation: Wurtz Reaction: 2 molecules of Chloroethane react with Sodium in dry ether to form Butane, effectively doubling the carbon chain length.

title: Fittig Reaction

steps.mechanism_hint: Fittig Reaction couples two Aryl halides.

explanation: First, brominate Benzene. Then, treat Iodobenzene/Bromobenzene with Sodium in dry ether (Fittig Reaction) to couple two phenyl rings, forming Diphenyl (Biphenyl).

title: Skeletal Rearrangement
description: Convert tert-Butyl Bromide to Isobutyl Bromide

steps.mechanism_hint: Anti-Markovnikov addition puts Br on the primary carbon.

explanation: Elimination gives Isobutylene. Anti-Markovnikov addition (HBr/Peroxide) places Br on the primary carbon, converting tert-butyl to isobutyl bromide.

title: Carbylamine Test

steps.mechanism_hint: Foul smelling Isocyanide formed. Test for Primary Amines.

explanation: Heating a primary amine (Aniline) with Chloroform and alcoholic KOH yields a foul-smelling Isocyanide (Phenyl Isocyanide). This reaction is specific to primary amines.

title: Directing Effects: Para

steps.mechanism_hint: Brominate FIRST. Bromine is ortho/para directing. If you nitrate first, you get meta.
Nitration on Bromobenzene gives Para isomer as major product due to steric hindrance at ortho.

explanation: Brominate benzene first (-Br is o/p directing). Then nitrate. The Para isomer is major due to steric factors. (Nitrating first would give m-Bromonitrobenzene).

title: Directing Effects: Meta

steps.mechanism_hint: Nitrate FIRST. The -NO2 group is Meta directing. If you chlorinate first, you get para.
Chlorination occurs at the meta position relative to the nitro group.

explanation: Nitrate benzene first (-NO2 is Meta directing). Then chlorinate. The incoming Cl+ ion attacks the meta position relative to the nitro group.

title: Synthesis of TNT Precursor

steps.mechanism_hint: Friedel-Crafts Alkylation adds the Methyl group (activator, o/p director).
Nitration yields p-nitrotoluene as the major product.

explanation: Friedel-Crafts Alkylation adds a Methyl group (o/p director). Nitration then occurs primarily at the Para position (less steric hindrance than ortho).

title: Ketone Synthesis

steps.mechanism_hint: Friedel-Crafts Acylation directly attaches the acetyl group.

explanation: Friedel-Crafts Acylation uses Acetyl Chloride (CH3COCl) and AlCl3 to substitute an H on the benzene ring with an Acyl group, forming Acetophenone.

title: Cyclic Polymerization (Easy)
explanation: Pass Ethyne through a red-hot iron tube at 873K. Three ethyne molecules undergo cyclic polymerization to form the aromatic Benzene ring.

title: Double Elimination Path

steps.mechanism_hint: Double elimination removes 2 HBr molecules to form Ethyne.

explanation: Add Bromine to form 1,2-Dibromoethane. Double elimination (Alc KOH then NaNH2) removes 2 HBr molecules to form Ethyne. Then polymerize to Benzene.

title: Aromatization

steps.mechanism_hint: Catalytic reforming (dehydrogenation + cyclization) converts alkanes to aromatics.

explanation: Catalytic reforming of n-Hexane over Mo2O3/V2O5 oxides at high temp/pressure causes dehydrogenation and cyclization to form Benzene.

title: Markovnikov Hydration

steps.mechanism_hint: Acid-catalyzed hydration follows Markovnikov's rule (OH goes to stable carbocation).

explanation: Acid-catalyzed hydration follows Markovnikov's rule. The carbocation intermediate forms on the secondary carbon, leading to Propan-2-ol.

title: Benzylic Substitution
description: Convert Benzyl Chloride to Benzyl Alcohol

steps.mechanism_hint: Simple Nucleophilic Substitution (SN2/SN1). OH replaces Cl.

explanation: Benzyl Chloride undergoes hydrolysis with aqueous KOH. The primary benzylic carbocation is somewhat stable, or SN2 occurs, replacing Cl with OH.

title: Grignard Synthesis (1° Alcohol)
description: Convert Ethyl Magnesium Chloride to Propan-1-ol

steps.mechanism_hint: Grignard attacks Methanal to extend chain by 1 carbon.
Acidic workup protonates the alkoxide to form alcohol.

explanation: Grignard reagent attacks Methanal (Formaldehyde) to add one carbon and form a primary alkoxide. Acid workup yields the primary alcohol.

title: Grignard Synthesis (3° Alcohol)

steps.mechanism_hint: Grignard attacks Ketone (Acetone) to form a Tertiary Alcohol.

explanation: Grignard reagent attacks Acetone (Ketone). The nucleophilic carbon adds to the carbonyl carbon, forming a tertiary alkoxide, then tertiary alcohol.

title: Cyclic Hydration

steps.mechanism_hint: Start with 1-Methylcyclohexene. Markovnikov addition puts OH on the tertiary carbon.

explanation: Mechanism follows Markovnikov addition. H+ adds to the double bond to form the stable tertiary cyclic carbocation. Water attacks there to form 1-Methylcyclohexanol.

title: Symmetrical Hydration

steps.mechanism_hint: Start with 4-Methylhept-3-ene. Hydration occurs at the more substituted carbon.

explanation: Hydration of the alkene. The double bond is symmetrical in position but substituents direct formation of the stable tertiary carbocation/alcohol.

title: Regioselective Hydration

steps.mechanism_hint: Start with Pent-1-ene. Markovnikov addition gives the secondary alcohol (2-ol).

explanation: Markovnikov addition to Pent-1-ene puts the positive charge on C2. Water attacks C2 to form Pentan-2-ol.

title: Complex Hydration

steps.mechanism_hint: Start with 2-Cyclohexylbut-2-ene. OH attacks the tertiary carbocation.

explanation: H+ attacks the double bond to form a tertiary carbocation at the branching point. Water attacks to yield the tertiary alcohol.

title: Synthesis: Methyl Benzoate
description: Convert Benzene to Methyl Benzoate (Using reagents with ≤1 Carbon)

steps.mechanism_hint: Friedel-Crafts Alkylation adds a Methyl group.
Strong oxidation converts the side chain to Benzoic Acid.

explanation: Friedel-Crafts Alkylation gives Toluene. KMnO4 oxidizes the methyl side chain to Benzoic Acid. Fischer Esterification with Methanol gives Methyl Benzoate.

title: Synthesis: m-Nitrobenzoic Acid

steps.mechanism_hint: Oxidize to Benzoic Acid. -COOH is a META directing group.
Nitration now occurs at the Meta position.

explanation: Alkylate to Toluene. Oxidize to Benzoic Acid (-COOH is Meta directing). Nitrate the Benzoic Acid to get the 'meta' nitro group.

title: Synthesis: p-Nitrobenzoic Acid

steps.mechanism_hint: Make Toluene. The Methyl group is Ortho/Para directing.
Nitrate first! We need the Para product before we oxidize.
Now oxidize the methyl group to acid.

explanation: Alkylate to Toluene (-CH3 is O/P directing). Nitrate Toluene to get p-Nitrotoluene. Then oxidize the methyl group to -COOH using KMnO4.

title: Conversion: Ketone to Alkene
explanation: Reduce Ketone to Secondary Alcohol using NaBH4. Then dehydrate with conc. H2SO4 to form the alkene.

title: Conversion: Acid to Aldehyde

steps.mechanism_hint: Rosenmund Reduction stops at the Aldehyde.

explanation: Convert Acid to Acid Chloride with SOCl2. Then perform Rosenmund Reduction (H2/Pd-BaSO4) which selectively stops reduction at the Aldehyde stage.

title: Conversion: Aldol Formation

steps.mechanism_hint: Aldol Condensation (without heat) gives beta-hydroxy aldehyde.

explanation: Oxidize Ethanol to Acetaldehyde (PCC). Dilute NaOH induces Aldol Condensation: alpha-hydrogen is removed, enolate attacks another aldehyde molecule.

title: Conversion: Grignard Addition

steps.mechanism_hint: Grignard adds Phenyl group to form Diphenylmethanol.

explanation: Phenyl Magnesium Bromide attacks Benzaldehyde to form Diphenylmethanol (2° alcohol). Oxidation with PCC yields Benzophenone.

title: Conversion: Cyanohydrin Path

steps.mechanism_hint: Complete hydrolysis of Nitrile gives Carboxylic Acid.

explanation: Nucleophilic addition of HCN (CN-) to the carbonyl group of Benzaldehyde forms a Cyanohydrin. Acid hydrolysis converts -CN to -COOH.

title: Conversion: Selective Reduction
description: Convert Benzoic Acid to m-Nitrobenzyl alcohol

steps.mechanism_hint: Diborane selectively reduces -COOH to -CH2OH without touching the Nitro group.

explanation: Nitrate Benzoic Acid (Meta product). Diborane (B2H6) selectively reduces Carboxylic Acids to Alcohols, leaving the Nitro group intact.

title: Step Down Series
description: Convert Ethanoic Acid to Methanamine (Remove 1 Carbon)

steps.mechanism_hint: Hoffmann Bromamide Degradation removes the carbonyl carbon.

explanation: Convert Acid to Amide (NH3/heat). Hoffmann Bromamide Degradation (Br2/KOH) removes the carbonyl carbon, producing an amine with one less carbon.

title: Step Down via Nitrile

steps.mechanism_hint: Hoffmann Bromamide Degradation removes one carbon.

explanation: Partial hydrolysis of nitriles yields Amides. Hoffmann Bromamide Degradation then chops off the carbonyl carbon to give the step-down amine.

title: Ascent of Series

steps.mechanism_hint: Complete hydrolysis converts Nitrile to Acid.

explanation: Methanol -> Chloromethane -> Acetonitrile (add C) -> Hydrolysis to Ethanoic Acid.

title: Amine Step Down

steps.mechanism_hint: Diazotization of aliphatic amine leads to Alcohol.

explanation: Amine -> Alcohol (HNO2). Alcohol -> Acid (KMnO4). Acid -> Amide. Amide -> Amine (Step Down via Hoffmann).

title: Amine Step Up

steps.mechanism_hint: Mendius reduction (or LiAlH4) converts Nitrile to Primary Amine.

explanation: Amine -> Alcohol. Alcohol -> Chloride. Chloride -> Nitrile (Step Up). Nitrile -> Amine (Reduction).

title: Nitro to Amine

steps.mechanism_hint: Reduction of Isocyanide gives Secondary Amine.

explanation: Reduce Nitro to Amine (Sn/HCl). Convert to Isocyanide (Carbylamine). Reduce Isocyanide (LiAlH4) to Secondary Amine.

title: Benzene to m-Bromophenol

steps.mechanism_hint: Hydrolysis of Diazonium salt yields Phenol.

explanation: Nitrate (Meta). Brominate (Meta to NO2). Reduce NO2 to NH2. Diazotize. Hydrolyze to OH.

title: Wurtz Reaction: C1 to C2

steps.mechanism_hint: Free radical substitution to Methyl Chloride.
Wurtz Reaction doubles the carbon chain.

explanation: The synthesis starts with chlorination of methane to form methyl chloride. Two molecules of methyl chloride then undergo a Wurtz reaction with sodium in dry ether to form ethane.

title: Wurtz Reaction: C2 to C4

steps.mechanism_hint: Wurtz coupling joins two ethyl groups.

explanation: Ethane is first brominated to ethyl bromide. The chain is then doubled using the Wurtz reaction (Na/Dry Ether) to produce n-butane.

title: Wurtz on Secondary Halide

steps.mechanism_hint: Coupling occurs at the secondary carbon (2-position).

explanation: HBr is added to but-1-ene via Markovnikov addition to yield 2-bromobutane. A Wurtz coupling then joins these secondary alkyl groups at the 2-position, forming 3,4-dimethylhexane.

title: Cyanide Ascent: Halide to Halide
description: Convert Methyl Iodide into Ethyl Iodide
explanation: Methyl iodide is converted to acetonitrile using KCN. Reduction with sodium and ethanol gives ethylamine, which is then converted to ethanol via diazotization. Finally, ethanol is converted to ethyl iodide using P+I2.

title: Cyanide Ascent: Alcohol to Alcohol
explanation: Methanol is activated to methyl iodide. KCN adds a carbon to form acetonitrile. Reduction gives ethylamine, and diazotization with HNO2 yields ethanol.

title: Ascent of Acid
description: Convert Acetic Acid to Propionic Acid

steps.mechanism_hint: Hydrolysis of Nitrile gives Carboxylic Acid.

explanation: Acetic acid is reduced to ethanol. Following conversion to ethyl iodide, KCN is used to form propionitrile. Acidic hydrolysis then yields propionic acid.

title: Ascent of Amine
explanation: Methylamine is converted to methanol using HNO2. Subsequent steps involve conversion to methyl iodide, nitrile formation with KCN to add a carbon, and reduction to ethylamine.

title: Grignard Ascent: C1 to C2
explanation: Methanol is converted to methyl iodide and then to a Grignard reagent (MeMgI). Reaction with formaldehyde followed by workup extends the chain to ethanol.

title: Grignard Ascent: C1 to C3

steps.mechanism_hint: Epoxide adds 2 Carbons to the chain.

explanation: Methanol is converted to methyl bromide and then to a Grignard reagent. Reaction with ethylene oxide extends the chain by two carbons to form propan-1-ol.

title: Grignard Ascent: C2 to C3

steps.mechanism_hint: Formaldehyde extends the chain by 1 Carbon.

explanation: Ethanol is converted to ethyl bromide and then to a Grignard reagent. Reaction with formaldehyde adds one carbon to form propan-1-ol.

title: Grignard: 2-Propanol Synthesis
explanation: Methanol is converted to methyl iodide and then to a Grignard reagent. Reaction with acetaldehyde yields 2-propanol (secondary alcohol).

title: Grignard: Oxidize then Add
explanation: Ethanol is oxidized to acetaldehyde. Methyl Grignard then attacks the carbonyl group to form 2-propanol upon workup.

title: Aldehyde Ascent

steps.mechanism_hint: Convert Formaldehyde to Ethanol via Grignard.

explanation: Formaldehyde is reacted with methyl Grignard to form ethanol. Dehydrogenation using copper at 573K then yields acetaldehyde.

title: Grignard Ascent: C2 to C4

steps.mechanism_hint: Epoxide adds 2 Carbons to the chain.

explanation: Ethanol is converted to ethyl bromide and the corresponding Grignard reagent. Reaction with ethylene oxide adds two carbons, yielding 1-butanol.

title: Descent: Ethane to Methane
description: Step down series: Convert Ethane into Methane

steps.mechanism_hint: Decarboxylation removes CO2 to form Methane.

explanation: Ethane is chlorinated to ethyl chloride and then hydrolyzed to ethanol. Strong oxidation yields acetic acid, which is neutralized to sodium acetate. Final decarboxylation with soda lime produces methane.

title: Decarboxylation
explanation: Propionic acid is converted to its sodium salt using NaOH. Heating with soda lime (decarboxylation) removes the carboxyl group as CO2, yielding ethane.

title: Hofmann Descent: Halide to Halide
description: Convert Ethyl Iodide to Methyl Iodide
explanation: Ethyl iodide is hydrolyzed to ethanol and then oxidized to acetic acid. Ammonolysis forms acetamide, which undergoes Hoffmann bromamide degradation to methylamine. Diazotization gives methanol, which is finally converted to methyl iodide.

title: Hofmann Descent: Alcohol to Alcohol
explanation: Ethanol is oxidized to acetic acid and converted to acetamide. Hoffmann degradation yields methylamine, which is then converted to methanol via diazotization.

title: Descent: Aldehyde to Aldehyde
explanation: Acetaldehyde is oxidized to acetic acid, then converted to acetamide and methylamine. Diazotization yields methanol, and final dehydrogenation with copper gives formaldehyde.

title: Descent: Amine to Amine
explanation: Ethylamine is converted to ethanol and then oxidized to acetic acid. Ammonolysis yields acetamide, which is degraded to methylamine via the Hoffmann bromamide reaction.

title: Descent: Amide to Amide
explanation: Propionamide is converted to ethylamine via Hoffmann degradation. Subsequent steps involve conversion to ethanol, oxidation to acetic acid, and final ammonolysis to yield acetamide.

title: Descent: Acid to Acid
description: Convert Propionic Acid to Acetic Acid
explanation: Propionic acid is converted to propionamide and then to ethylamine. Diazotization yields ethanol, which is then oxidized to acetic acid.

title: Acid to Secondary Alcohol
description: Convert Propionic Acid to Isopropyl Alcohol

steps.mechanism_hint: Grignard adds Methyl group to form Isopropyl Alcohol.

explanation: Propionic acid is stepped down to ethanol and then oxidized to acetaldehyde. Reaction with methyl Grignard followed by workup yields isopropyl alcohol.

title: Alkyne to Alcohol
explanation: Hydration of acetylene using HgSO4/H2SO4 gives acetaldehyde. Reduction with LiAlH4 then yields ethanol.

title: Alkyne to Acid
explanation: Acetylene is hydrated to acetaldehyde, which is then oxidized to acetic acid using a strong oxidizing agent.

title: Acid to Ketone (Dry Distillation)

steps.mechanism_hint: Heating Calcium salt yields Acetone + CaCO3.

explanation: Acetic acid is neutralized with calcium hydroxide to form calcium acetate. Dry distillation of the salt yields acetone.

title: Acid to Aldehyde
explanation: Acetic acid is converted to acetyl chloride using PCl5. Controlled reduction using the Rosenmund method (H2/Pd-BaSO4) yields acetaldehyde.

title: Dry Distillation (C1)
explanation: Formic acid is converted to calcium formate. Dry distillation of this salt yields formaldehyde.

title: Dry Distillation (C3)
explanation: Propionic acid is converted to calcium propionate. Dry distillation yields 3-pentanone (diethyl ketone).

title: Grignard Carboxylation
description: Convert Methyl Bromide to Acetic Acid (Grignard Method)

steps.mechanism_hint: Grignard attack on CO2 creates a Carboxylic Acid.

explanation: Methyl bromide is converted to a Grignard reagent (MeMgBr). Reaction with solid CO2 followed by hydrolysis yields acetic acid.

title: Position Shift: 1 to 2

steps.mechanism_hint: Markovnikov addition places Br on 2° Carbon.

explanation: 1-Propanol is dehydrated to propene using conc. H2SO4. Markovnikov addition of HBr then places bromine at the secondary carbon, yielding 2-bromopropane.

title: Alkyne Step Up
explanation: Propyne is deprotonated by NaNH2 to form sodium propynide. Nucleophilic attack on methyl iodide then adds a methyl group to yield 2-butyne.

title: Ascent to Amine
description: Convert Ethyl Chloride to n-Propyl Amine
explanation: Ethyl chloride is converted to propionitrile using KCN, extending the chain by one carbon. Reduction with LiAlH4 yields n-propyl amine.

title: Alkane to Alkene
explanation: Free radical chlorination of propane yields isopropyl chloride (major). Dehydrohalogenation with alcoholic KOH then produces propylene.

title: Alkene to Alkyne

steps.mechanism_hint: Double elimination removes 2 HBr to form Triple Bond.

explanation: Propylene is brominated to 1,2-dibromopropane. Double elimination using alcoholic KOH and NaNH2 removes two molecules of HBr to form the triple bond of propyne.

title: Williamson's Synthesis Path
description: Convert Ethyl Alcohol to Diethyl Ether

steps.mechanism_hint: Williamson's Synthesis: Nucleophilic attack by Ethoxide on Alkyl Halide.

explanation: Ethanol is converted to ethyl iodide using P/I2. Nucleophilic substitution with sodium ethoxide (Williamson's synthesis) then yields diethyl ether.

title: HVZ Reaction
description: Convert Propionic Acid to Lactic Acid

steps.mechanism_hint: Nucleophilic substitution replaces Br with OH.

explanation: Propionic acid undergoes HVZ reaction with Br2/Red P to form alpha-bromopropionic acid. Substitution with aqueous NaOH replaces the bromine with a hydroxyl group to form lactic acid.

title: Cyanohydrin Synthesis

steps.mechanism_hint: Hydrolysis of Nitrile group gives Carboxylic Acid.

explanation: Acetaldehyde reacts with HCN to form acetaldehyde cyanohydrin. Acidic hydrolysis of the nitrile group then gives lactic acid.

title: Alkyne to Aldol

steps.mechanism_hint: Aldol Condensation links two Acetaldehyde molecules.

explanation: Ethyne is hydrated using HgSO4/dil H2SO4 to form acetaldehyde. Dilute base then catalyzes aldol condensation between two acetaldehyde molecules to yield 3-hydroxybutanal.

title: Grignard Oxidation

steps.mechanism_hint: Oxidation of Secondary Alcohol yields Ketone.

explanation: Acetaldehyde reacts with methyl Grignard followed by acidic workup to form 2-propanol. Controlled oxidation of this secondary alcohol yields acetone.

title: Aldol Dehydration

steps.mechanism_hint: Dehydration removes water to form double bond (En-al).

explanation: Acetaldehyde undergoes aldol condensation to form 3-hydroxybutanal. Heating with acid causes dehydration of the beta-hydroxy aldehyde to form 2-butenal (crotonaldehyde).

title: Baeyer's Unsaturation
explanation: Ethanol is dehydrated to ethylene using conc. H2SO4 at 443K. Baeyer's reagent (cold dil. alk. KMnO4) then performs syn-hydroxylation to yield 1,2-ethanediol (glycol).

title: Nitro to Amine Step Up
explanation: Nitromethane is reduced to methylamine using Sn/HCl. Subsequent alkylation with methyl iodide via Hofmann's ammonolysis yields dimethylamine.

title: Methane to Acid
explanation: Methane is brominated to methyl bromide. Reaction with alcoholic KCN adds a carbon to form acetonitrile, which is then hydrolyzed to acetic acid.

title: Coupling Salts
description: Convert Formic Acid to Oxalic Acid

steps.mechanism_hint: Thermal coupling releases H2 to form Sodium Oxalate.

explanation: Formic acid is neutralized to sodium formate. Thermal coupling at 633K releases hydrogen to form sodium oxalate, which is then acidified to oxalic acid.

title: Oxidative Cleavage Prep

steps.mechanism_hint: Oxidative Cleavage (Note: Text says Baeyer's but implies strong oxidation/cleavage path for Oxalic Acid).

explanation: Ethylene is brominated to 1,2-dibromoethane and then dehydrobrominated to acetylene. Strong oxidation (cleavage) of acetylene yields oxalic acid.

title: Isomerization of Alcohol
description: Convert Isobutyl Alcohol to tert-Butyl Alcohol

steps.mechanism_hint: Iodine adds to the Tertiary carbon.

explanation: Isobutyl alcohol is dehydrated to isobutylene. Markovnikov addition of HI places iodine at the tertiary carbon, and substitution with AgOH yields tert-butyl alcohol.

title: Dinitrile Synthesis

steps.mechanism_hint: Complete hydrolysis of both CN groups.

explanation: Ethylene is converted to 1,2-dibromoethane. Double substitution with KCN yields succinonitrile, which is then fully hydrolyzed to succinic acid.

title: Anti-Markovnikov Shift
description: Convert Isopropyl Alcohol to n-Propyl Alcohol
explanation: Isopropyl alcohol is dehydrated to propene. Anti-Markovnikov addition of HBr (Kharasch effect) yields n-propyl bromide, which is then hydrolyzed to n-propyl alcohol.

title: Dry Distillation Path

steps.mechanism_hint: Heat Calcium salt to release Acetone.

explanation: Acetaldehyde is oxidized to acetic acid and neutralized to calcium acetate. Dry distillation of the salt yields acetone.

title: Markovnikov Shift
description: Convert n-Propyl Alcohol to Isopropyl Alcohol
explanation: n-Propyl alcohol is dehydrated to propene. Markovnikov addition of HI yields 2-iodopropane, which is then hydrolyzed to isopropyl alcohol.

title: Ketone to Amide

steps.mechanism_hint: Strong oxidation of Ketone breaks C-C bond to Acetic Acid.

explanation: Acetone undergoes strong oxidation with conc. HNO3, breaking a C-C bond to form acetic acid. This is converted to acetyl chloride and then to acetamide via ammonolysis.

title: Grignard: Double Addition
description: Convert Acetic Acid to tert-Butyl Alcohol

steps.mechanism_hint: Two equivalents of Methyl Grignard attack the ester to form a Tertiary Alcohol.

explanation: Acetic acid is first converted to ethyl acetate via Fischer esterification. Two equivalents of methyl magnesium bromide (Grignard reagent) then attack the ester carbonyl, followed by acidic workup, to produce tert-butyl alcohol.

title: Dry Distillation Path
explanation: Ethanol is oxidized to acetic acid using a strong oxidizing agent. Neutralization with calcium hydroxide forms calcium acetate, which upon dry distillation yields acetone.

title: Ketone Aldol (Diacetone Alcohol)
description: Convert Ethanoic Acid to Diacetone Alcohol

steps.mechanism_hint: Convert Acid to Acetone via Calcium salt.

explanation: Ethanoic acid is converted to acetone via its calcium salt. Acetone then undergoes base-catalyzed aldol condensation (using Ba(OH)2 or dil. NaOH) to form diacetone alcohol (a ketol).

title: Acid Chloride to Amine
explanation: Propanoic acid is converted to propanoyl chloride using SOCl2, then to propionamide with ammonia. The amide undergoes Hoffmann bromamide degradation (Br2/KOH) to produce ethylamine, stepping down the carbon chain.

title: Inorganic to Organic Halide

steps.mechanism_hint: Exhaustive chlorination replaces all H with Cl.

explanation: Calcium carbide reacts with water to give acetylene, which is reduced to ethane. Exhaustive free-radical chlorination of ethane in excess chlorine and sunlight yields hexachloroethane.

title: Organocadmium Synthesis

steps.mechanism_hint: Organocadmium reagents yield Ketones from Acid Chlorides (won't react further).

explanation: Acetic acid is converted to acetyl chloride. Reaction with diethylcadmium yields the ketone (butanone) without further addition. Finally, LiAlH4 reduces the ketone to the secondary alcohol, 2-butanol.

title: Claisen Condensation
explanation: Acetaldehyde is oxidized to acetic acid and then esterified to ethyl acetate. Two molecules of ethyl acetate undergo Claisen condensation in the presence of sodium ethoxide to form acetoacetic ester (a beta-keto ester).

title: Geminal to Vicinal Halide

steps.mechanism_hint: Addition of Chlorine gives Vicinal Dichloride.

explanation: 1,1-Dichloroethane is dehydrohalogenated with alcoholic KOH to ethyne. Controlled reduction with Lindlar's catalyst gives ethene, and final addition of chlorine across the double bond yields 1,2-dichloroethane (vicinal dichloride).

title: Alkyne to Ketone
explanation: Acetylene is hydrated to acetaldehyde using HgSO4/H2SO4. Acetaldehyde is oxidized to acetic acid, which is then converted to acetone via dry distillation of its calcium salt.

title: Vinyl Ester Synthesis
description: Convert Ethyl Alcohol to Vinyl Acetate

steps.mechanism_hint: Addition of Acetic Acid to Alkyne gives Vinyl Acetate.

explanation: Ethanol is dehydrated to ethene and then brominated to 1,2-dibromoethane. Double dehydrobromination gives acetylene. Finally, the addition of acetic acid to acetylene in the presence of HgSO4 yields vinyl acetate.

title: Inorganic to Aromatic
explanation: Calcium carbonate is converted to calcium carbide via lime and carbon. Hydrolysis of the carbide gives acetylene, which undergoes cyclic polymerization in a red-hot copper tube to form benzene.

title: Ascent of Amine
explanation: Propanoic acid is reduced to 1-propanol and then converted to 1-bromopropane. Reaction with alcoholic KCN extends the chain to butyronitrile, which is reduced with LiAlH4 to n-butylamine.

title: Grignard Wurtz Combo
explanation: Formaldehyde reacts with methyl Grignard to form ethanol. Ethanol is converted to ethyl bromide, which then undergoes the Wurtz reaction with sodium in ether to double the carbon chain and form n-butane.

title: Oxidative Cleavage of Alkene
description: Convert Ethanoic Acid to Methanoic Acid + Diphenyl Ketone

steps.mechanism_hint: Double Grignard adds 2 Phenyl groups (Tertiary Alcohol).
Oxidative cleavage gives Benzophenone + Formic Acid.

explanation: Acetic acid is esterified to ethyl acetate. Two equivalents of phenyl Grignard add to the ester to form 1,1-diphenylethanol. Dehydration gives 1,1-diphenylethylene, which undergoes oxidative cleavage with strong KMnO4 to yield benzophenone and methanoic acid.

title: Aldol from Anhydride
explanation: Ethanoic anhydride is reduced to ethanol, which is then dehydrogenated to ethanal. Ethanal undergoes aldol condensation to 3-hydroxybutanal, followed by acidic dehydration to form 2-butenal (crotonaldehyde).
